overview_of_class: This course explores techniques for describing the real world with numbers and for making educated guesses about how the world works by manipulating these numbers. Students acquire a knowledge of how to execute statistical tests, but more importantly when and why to execute these tests. Emphasis is placed on understanding and interpreting data as well as on techniques of statistical analysis. A secondary goal of this course is to provide a framework from which to think critically about statistical evidence presented in the media and research reports from journals in psychology. Classes will consist of lecture and problem-based group work. The assessments include in-class quizzes, exams, a series of in-class "team" problem sets, take home problem sets, and a short paper analyzing the use of statistical information in the media. May not be audited. Carries social science or science credit.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: After completing this course, you will be able to summarize datasets using a variety of descriptive statistics, test for relationships between variables, and make group comparisons using inferential statistics. You will also be able to understand scientific notation that you may encounter when reading journal articles in other courses and in your own research.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Class participation, discussion, group work, problem sets, readings, writing assignments

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Midterm and final exam
Group work (8 in-class problem sets)
Homework (6 take-home problem sets)
Quizzes (6 in-class short quizzes)
Writing assignment (one 1-2 page paper)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Materials may include the following:

Scientific calculator.

Glenberg, A. & Andrzejewski, M. (2008). Learning from Data: An Introduction to Statistical Reasoning (3rd Edition) Mahwah, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum. ISBN: 0 -8058-4921-1.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: This course is not designed to: (1) scare you; (2) create intense amounts of math anxiety; or (3) turn you off to the field of psychology. I will do my best to ensure that, at the end of the course, you will find yourself reflecting, "Wow, that wasn't all that bad!"
